author: Kevinement
body:
If you’re honestly looking into starting to save money, I wouldn’t recommend blowing it in trades. Day-Trading is a super risky business even for well-experiences stock market experts.  
Just buy broadly diversified ETFs with low TER, like an MSCI World and use the buy and hold strategy.

There’s a reason why Wall Street gets constantly jokes about blowing all their money. It’s not a joke.

author: Fredbull
body:
Hi everyone, European here looking to start investing.

Given the high tax over dividends in my country, and given that I want to hold my positions for a long time, I was looking for an accumulating ETF that tracked the S&P500 and purchasable through Degiro.

I was looking at **iShares Core S&P 500 UCITS ETF** and the page looked good, didn't see any red flags, and the TER isn't terribly high. Also it's available through my broker (Degiro).

Does anyone have any idea if this is a good option?

Thanks a lot!!

author: Kbarbs4421
body:
I'm coming around on Terrascend.  I like that their investment capex for expansion is nearly complete. As they bring these markets online and/or ramp their footprints, financial performance should be quite strong relative to peers.  I also like the Canopy relationship, and have noted their increasing preference to discuss Terrascend rather than Acreage.  It certainly feels like Terrascend is viewed as a winning investment by CGC.

I finally opened a modest position in TRSSF earlier this week, right at the recent support level.  I have a couple of deeper limit buys set should support fail.  If pps holds and climbs from here, I don't feel the need to chase.  As one of the best positioned companies outside of the top tier, I'm happy to have a bit of exposure going into this phase of MSO growth.

That said, I'm channeling the lessons I learned during the LP bubble.  In particular, I'm committed to taking profit and closing out positions on mid-tier names when things get nuts.  Terrascend is not a long hold for me, barring some sort of major shift in strategy or success.  When the US cannacraze happens, I'm going to winnow my exposure down to a couple of core long positions in the best run companies at that time.  Even if TER is looking really good mid-bubble, I'm going to accept that for the win it is and move on with my gains.  I'm not going to ride over the top of another wave holding onto underdogs.

FWIW, I think it's important to note that Terrascend is beholden to two major insiders (Canopy and JW Asset Management).  So much so that common shareholders are certainly an after thought.  Also, so much so that those insiders should be viewed skeptically as possible vultures looking to force a takeover in the end.  In other words, Terrascend may prove to be a good company that's not a great investment for the common shareholder.  It's important not to lose sight of that as a possibility.

author: ZombehArmyLTD
body:
Youre like 4 years too late to make a million but youll still do good if you invest in some of the best tickers at the right averages.

Canadian side, only APHA sub C6$, or WEED sub C20$.
Stateside, CURA sub C9$, TRUL sub C20$ and GTII sub C16$. 

Some YOLO plays for me would be PLTH sub C3$, TER sub C5$.

Id wait it out. This sub seems to think itll run all the way until legalization.. i dont believe it but, you can bet with them. Youll probably be fine if you know how to take profits when they come. 

Id kick the millionaire thoughts out the door unless you plan on holding for 15+ years. 

Good luck!

author: wegwerf874
body:
There are enough UCITS-compliant ETF you can buy from the EU which are basically equivalent to VOO or VTI but without all the tax-related cross-border hassle (these are highly non-trivial for ETFs, just filing a W8-BEN won't be enough). Their TER are also as low as 0,07%. Of course, you will have currency issues, i.e. the value per share which is often denominated in EUR will vary depending on the exchange rate, but so would it be if you bought shares at a US-based broker. You can also see exchange rates as a virtue: Currently, for example, all US shares are on a 10% discount for Europeans, compared with a few months ago.

Just look into EU-based products by, e.g., iShares (Blackrock), x-trackers (Deutsche), Vanguard, SPDR etc. pp.

author: radarbot
body:
This is kind of my strategy too. I have a few different piles based on doing research of active invested fund portfolios, industry trends and my own gut feeling:

1. Cloud computing (ie. NET, FSLY, etc)
2. Digital communications (ie. TWLO, BAND, ORBC, NOK etc)
3. Modernized Healthcare (ie. CRSP, NVTA, ARCT, TDOC, LVGO, etc)
4. Renewable Energy (ie. SPWR, SEDG, RUN, BEP, NEE, etc)
5. Ecommerce (ie. SQ, V, PYPL, etc)
6. Tech hardware (ie. AMD, AMAT, MU, TSM, TER,)

I've tried a DCA average into most of these stocks, but the current run up has been savage on my mental strain as some of these stocks are moving much faster than I expected, which is fucking with my DCA strategy.

Thanks for your response, I think we're all in the same boat and its all about discipline in this whacky market.

author: daccord_cava
body:
that's right, the expensive ones will keep getting more expensive (it remains to be seen whether they'll retain their valuations tho)

i think we've all gotten accustomed to seeing sympathy runs on turds just because they're "in the sector" but there does seem to be some separation occurring (`MMEN` for example)...

i do think there are still some diamonds in the rough out there that have some arb in them... toddo just mentioned `AYR.A` but last i checked their execution still looked like trash...

there's been a lot of mention of `TER` by him as well and they did well with their recent pre-announcement, but all I remember about `TER` is their former-founder's twitter-fights and the shit-ass liquidity (plus i think it's still majority-controlled by the one family-fund)... price-action doesn't lie though so maybe there's something to it... i should look into them
